III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404 Placement
Section • (4) An agency shall consider all the following factors in
Description selecting an appropriate placement for a child:
• (h) The continuity of relationships, including
relationships with parents, siblings, relatives, foster
parents, previous foster parents, and other persons
significant to the child.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency facilitated a change in placement with Youth A and
Youth B and did not replace them into the home of a previous
caregiver.
Investigation Interviews:
I interviewed Caregiver by phone on 08/04/2025. Caregiver
stated the children were doing well in Caregiver’s home but were
removed to be placed with a relative. Caregiver stated the
children were involved in another move that did not include a
return to the Caregiver 's home or the placement with a relative.
Caregiver stated Caregiver would have liked to have had the
children returned to Caregiver's home. Caregiver reported they
appealed the children's removal from their home when they were
placed with a relative. Caregiver described Mother of the children
as not liking Caregiver or getting along with Caregiver.
I interviewed Chief Administrator and Program Manager by
phone on 10/01/2025. They reported the children were replaced
from Caregiver's home to a relative placement. Chief
Administrator and Program Manager reported this case was
subsequently transferred to another agency on 4/04/2025 due to
staffing shortages for this agency. Chief Administrator and
Program Manager stated Caregiver had appealed the removal of
the children to the Foster Care Review Board at the time of the
relative placement. The findings of the Foster Care Review Board
were supportive of the change in placement. Chief Administrator
and Program Manager reported two concerns when the children
were placed with Caregiver. One concern was Caregiver did not
get along with Mother of the children and Mother did not want the
children placed with Caregiver. A second concern was that a
foster home special evaluation had to be completed with
Caregiver when an allegation was made Caregiver used physical
discipline with the children by slapping their hands when they
wrote on the wall/furniture of the home. Although no marks or
bruises were noted as a part of the special investigation,
Caregiver admitted that form of discipline at the time. Chief
Administrator and Program Manager reported a return to the
Caregiver was considered, but not pursued due to concerns
related to discipline methods, the need for a corrective action plan
following the determination of a special evaluation that was
completed, opposition by the mother of the children for placement
with Caregiver, and Caregiver’s difficult relationship with the
mother.
2

I interviewed Foster Care Worker by phone on 10/10/2025.
Foster Care Worker reported the placement consideration
situation consistent with the description reported by Chief
Administrator and Program Manager.
Documents Reviewed:
I reviewed the Foster Care Review Board findings and
determination the Foster Care Review Board was supportive of
the agency's change in placement from Caregiver’s home to the
relative/fictive kin home.
I reviewed Foster Home evaluations and the special investigation
report on the home of Caregiver. The findings of the special
evaluation included Caregiver admitting to the inappropriate
discipline and the development of a corrective action plan.
I reviewed the placement records of the children. The placement
record indicated placement in the home of Caregiver from
08/13/2024 to 12/06/2024, Relative/Fictive Kin 12/06/2024-
03/10/2025, and 03/10/2025-5/13/2025 in another licensed foster
home. The case management/supervision was transferred to
another agency 04/04/2025.
I reviewed the TDM meeting associated with the children’s move
from Caregiver’s home to the relative/fictive kin dated 11/21/2024.
This TDM was initiated in response to the mother of the children
requesting the children be placed with the relative/fictive kin.
Caregiver was invited but chose to not attend/participate in this
meeting if the children were going to be moved. One of the
concerns of the mother of the children associated with Caregiver
was the Caregiver encouraged/allowed the children to call her
“Mama C” despite the mother asking Caregiver not to.
I reviewed the TDM dated 03/07/2025 associated with the
children’s change in placement from the relative/fictive kin
placement. Participants identified in this TDM were the
relative/fictive kin caregiver, agency foster care worker, agency
supervisor (Program Manager), children’s paternal grandmother,
MDHHS POS supervisor, agency licensing specialist, and
MDHHS Facilitator. It was noted Caregiver was not invited due to
previously reported concerns related to the care of the children.
The plan associated with this TDM was to assess the paternal
grandmother for placement while the children were in a
temporary/short term foster home placement. The case
management supervision of this case was transferred from this
agency shortly following the completion of this TDM.
3

I reviewed the Placement Selection Criteria rating for the
placement of Youth A and Youth B in the home of Caregiver. This
placement selection criteria identified a rating of 4 for placement
with relative, a rating of 4 for religious preference, and a rating of 4
associated with the expressed preference by the child. This scale
is rated from 1-4 with 1 being the best/highest rating/preference
and 4 the worst.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with the rule per interviews
and case files reviewed. It was found the agency considered
Caregiver, but placement was not facilitated due to the identified
previous concerns.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
